block.p: Re "When Winter's Reality Hits Home" (Editorial Notebook, Jan. 11): I agree with Richard E. Mooney that the Blizzard of 1888 still ranks as the most powerful snowstorm to strike modern New York City, despite the intensity of our recent barrage and the 26-inch storm of 1947.

Re "When Winter's Reality Hits Home" (Editorial Notebook, Jan. 11): I agree with Richard E. Mooney that the Blizzard of 1888 still ranks as the most powerful snowstorm to strike modern New York City, despite the intensity of our recent barrage and the 26-inch storm of 1947.
But the winter of 1887-88, before the surprise of the blizzard, was not "the mildest winter in 16 years."

Not only were there several previous winters whose monthly temperatures were higher, especially 1879-80 and 1877-78, but they and several others also had less snow than the near-normal seasonal accumulation of 23.5 inches measured in Central Park before the 1888 storm.

The explanation for the "mildest winter" error is that in the several weeks before the blizzard, the weather was less cold and snowy than it had been. The thermometer even rose into the 40's and 50's on a few days in late February and early March. At least one local writer must have exaggerated this short-term mildness as unprecedented and thus began the "mild winter" of 1888.
The writer is a climate researcher and historian.
